1980

Honourable mention

Van Halen - Women and Children First

When Van Halen burst onto the scene they undeniably took it apart (more on that later), and they were still pretty much at the top of their game by the third album. Punchy. Top track: â€œEverybody Wants Some!!â€

Winner

AC/DC - Back in Black

Well. I know Iâ€™m going to get into trouble in some quarters, but for me AC/DC has a Geordie singer with a flat cap. I know, I know, and all you O.G. Bon Scott loving fans can go right ahead and tell me how wrong I am, but Iâ€™ll just smile and stick this album on again. Of course itâ€™s a tragedy how BS died, of course he was taken too early, naturally he was a huge part of how the band achieved their success to begin with. Iâ€™m not arguing with any of that. But for me, this is THE AC/DC album, and no amount of â€œBeating Around the Bushâ€, â€œBig Ballsâ€ or â€œTNTâ€ is going to change that.

Top tracks: â€œHells Bellsâ€, â€œYou Shook Me All Night Longâ€, â€œBack in Blackâ€

1979

Honourable mentions

AC/DC - Highway to Hell

Now thatâ€™s not to say that I donâ€™t like Bon Scott, by the wayâ€¦ I just prefer Johnson. But on this, Scottâ€™s final album, he was pretty damned amazing and Angus is absolutely out of control. Top track: â€œHighway to Hellâ€

Van Halen - Van Halen II

Ah, Van Halen, you say? Well yes. Their second album has some crackers on it, and the musical pyrotechnics of EVH are if anything a little more harnessed than on the debut. Just a little filler here, but mostly killer. Top track: â€œLight Up the Skyâ€

Winner

Pink Floyd - The Wall

So you thought you might like to go to the show?

If youâ€™re going to concept album, this is how you do it. (Iâ€™m looking at you, Dream Theater.) An introvert odyssey into isolation and what boils down to PTSD and depression, this 81-minute cheery tale of one young manâ€™s breakdown and consequent regression inside himself is a prog masterpiece, one of the few of the era that I can actually tolerate, laden as it is with drama and melody from the get-go. Total boner-fido classic, and the only example that comes to mind of a justifiable double album. Go on, name one other (discounting live albums and soundtracks) that wouldnâ€™t be better boiled down to a single albumâ€¦ You canâ€™t. But this is worth every second.

Top tracks: â€œComfortably Numbâ€, â€œMotherâ€, â€œAnother Brick in the Wall pt. 2â€

1978

Honourable mentions

Dire Straits - Dire Straits

This may in fact be my favourite Dire Straits album. Thereâ€™s a prowling moodiness to the lyrics and Mark Knopflerâ€™s lead guitar crackles throughout. â€œSultans of Swingâ€ indeed. Top track: â€œDown to the Waterlineâ€

Brian Eno - Ambient 1: Music for Airports

Ambient music is not for everyone, but if it is even mildly your bag then you need this. High water mark. Top track: â€œ1/1â€

Winner

Van Halen - Van Halen

Are you kidding me? I frequently wax lyrical about the greatest debut album of all time being Appetite For Destruction in 1987, which it is, but this has to be right behind it.

I canâ€™t imagine being the rock music industry when this thing hit it. I imagine it must have had to go and have a bit of a lie down.

Top tracks: â€œAinâ€™t Talkinâ€™ 'Bout Loveâ€, â€œAtomic Punkâ€, â€œRunninâ€™ With the Devilâ€

1977

Dishonourable mention

The Sex Pistols - Never Mind the Bollocksâ€¦

I was never into punk, not even a little bit, but it definitely happened, of that much we can be sure. It transpires that this is actually pretty good, even now. Top track: â€œPretty Vacantâ€

Winner

Fleetwood Mac - Rumours

Retroactively, for sure, though many of the Mac tracks I grew up loving seem to have come from this album, so why not? Wikipedia tells me that following the previous eponymous album the bandâ€™s two couples â€“ Christine & John McVie and Buckingham/Nicks â€“ had split up (as well as drummer Mick Fleetwood going through a divorce of his own), lending a certain frisson to the writing process for this, later claimed to be their most important album of all time (and the bandâ€™s 11th overall).

Whether you have any time for Fleetwood Mac or not, they were one of the bigger bands of this era and I grew up with many of these songs on the radio, and I still love them. So there.

Top tracks: â€œDreamsâ€, â€œGo Your Own Wayâ€, â€œThe Chainâ€
